The base of the natural logarithm raised to the power of 0 equals 1. (equivalent to $e^0 = 1$)

name: Real.exp_zero
docString: The base of the natural logarithm raised to the power of 0 equals 1. (equivalent to $e^0 = 1$)

The theorem states that for any natural number `n`, if `n` modulo 4 equals 3, then raising `-1` to the power of `n` divided by 2 equals `-1`. In other words, for any natural number that leaves a remainder of 3 when divided by 4, if we take half of that number as the exponent of `-1`, the result will be `-1`.

name: ZMod.neg_one_pow_div_two_of_three_mod_four
docString: The theorem states that for any natural number `n`, if `n` modulo 4 equals 3, then raising `-1` to the power of `n` divided by 2 equals `-1`. In other words, for any natural number that leaves a remainder of 3 when divided by 4, if we take half of that number as the exponent of `-1`, the result will be `-1`.

For any `n`, we have `log_stirlingSeq 1 - log_stirlingSeq n ≤ 1/4 * ∑' 1/k^2`

name: Stirling.log_stirlingSeq_bounded_aux
docString: For any `n`, we have `log_stirlingSeq 1 - log_stirlingSeq n ≤ 1/4 * ∑' 1/k^2`

For any linear ordered semifield and floor semiring type R, and natural number b and real number r, if r ≤ 0 then Int.log b r = 0.

type: ∀ {R : Type u_1} [inst : LinearOrderedSemifield R] [inst_1 : FloorSemiring R] (b : ℕ) {r : R}, r ≤ 0 → Int.log b r = 0
name: Int.log_of_right_le_zero
docString: For any linear ordered semifield and floor semiring type R, and natural number b and real number r, if r ≤ 0 then Int.log b r = 0.

The theorem `Real.log_one` states that the logarithm of 1 in the real numbers is equal to 0. This is a standard result in mathematics, as any number raised to the power of 0 is 1, so the logarithm, being the inverse operation to exponentiation, must give 0 when applied to 1. This result holds true under the definition of the real logarithm function in Lean 4 whether 1 is considered a positive real number, or when it's equal to 0.

name: Real.log_one
docString: The theorem `Real.log_one` states that the logarithm of 1 in the real numbers is equal to 0. This is a standard result in mathematics, as any number raised to the power of 0 is 1, so the logarithm, being the inverse operation to exponentiation, must give 0 when applied to 1. This result holds true under the definition of the real logarithm function in Lean 4 whether 1 is considered a positive real number, or when it's equal to 0.

If `n % 4 = 3`, then `χ₄ n = -1`.

name: ZMod.χ₄_int_three_mod_four
docString: If `n % 4 = 3`, then `χ₄ n = -1`.

If `n % 4 = 1`, then `χ₄ n = 1`.

name: ZMod.χ₄_nat_one_mod_four
docString: If `n % 4 = 1`, then `χ₄ n = 1`.

The real logarithm function tends to `+∞` at `+∞`.

name: Real.tendsto_log_atTop
docString: The real logarithm function tends to `+∞` at `+∞`.

The value of `χ₄ n`, for `n : ℤ`, depends only on `n % 4`.

name: ZMod.χ₄_int_mod_four
docString: The value of `χ₄ n`, for `n : ℤ`, depends only on `n % 4`.

Represent `log (1 - z)⁻¹` as an integral over the unit interval

type: ∀ {z : ℂ}, 1 - z ∈ Complex.slitPlane → Complex.log (1 - z)⁻¹ = z * ∫ (t : ℝ) in 0 ..1, (1 - t • z)⁻¹
name: Complex.log_inv_eq_integral
docString: Represent `log (1 - z)⁻¹` as an integral over the unit interval

The right_inv direction of the equivalence

type:
∀ {w : List ℕ} {hw : List.Sorted (fun x x_1 => x ≥ x_1) w},
  (∀ x ∈ w, 0 < x) → YoungDiagram.rowLens (YoungDiagram.ofRowLens w hw) = w
name: YoungDiagram.rowLens_ofRowLens_eq_self
docString: The right_inv direction of the equivalence

  YoungDiagram.ofRowLens (YoungDiagram.rowLens μ) (_ : List.Sorted (fun x x_1 => x ≥ x_1) (YoungDiagram.rowLens μ)) = μ

docString: The left_inv direction of the equivalence

The value of the quadratic character at `-1`

type:
∀ {F : Type u_1} [inst : Field F] [inst_1 : Fintype F] [inst_2 : DecidableEq F],
  ringChar F ≠ 2 → (quadraticChar F) (-1) = ZMod.χ₄ ↑(Fintype.card F)

docString: The value of the quadratic character at `-1`

Taylor's formula.

type:
∀ {R : Type u_2} [inst : CommRing R] (f : Polynomial R) (r : R),
  (Polynomial.sum ((Polynomial.taylor r) f) fun i a => Polynomial.C a * (Polynomial.X - Polynomial.C r) ^ i) = f
name: Polynomial.sum_taylor_eq
docString: Taylor's formula.

`arsinh` is defined using a logarithm, `arsinh x = log (x + sqrt(1 + x^2))`.

name: Real.arsinh
docString: `arsinh` is defined using a logarithm, `arsinh x = log (x + sqrt(1 + x^2))`.
